title: In The Great Gatsby, how does Wilson see the eyes of Doctor T.J? Does Wilson's statement have a symbolic level for the novel as a whole? - Quora

response.answer_text: As Robert Girard mentioned, Wilson indeed sees the eyes of Doctor T. J. as the eyes of god. However the location is very interesting : it’s on a billboard, which reflects the materialism and superficial lifestyle of society in the 1920′s. This could mean that god get’s replaced by consumerism and that he’s losing his dominance as a result. But Fitzgerald’s narration often seems to suggest that the objects (the eyes of Doctor T. J. in this case) only hold a meaning because characters inflict them with a meaning.

He thinks the eyes are those of God. When he sees his dead wife, he thinks God is telling him to seek revenge for her death. As to whether that has a symbolic meaning for the novel as a whole, what do you think?
